item.title: Why Is Istio That Shape?
item.description: Session Information Conference Link Abstract Services Meshes are growing in relevance and adoption, as you can see from all the intro talks out there. But how do you build one of these things? Part network, part service discovery system, part logging adaptor, and 100% distributed system, it’s not easy. So why is the most popular service mesh, Istio, the shape it is? We’ll see how the design fits the traditional three-tier model better than you think.

item.title: The Life of a Packet Through Istio - Deep dive
The Life of a Packet Through Istio - Deep dive
item.description: Video Session Information Conference Link Abstract Istio is a service mesh for Kubernetes that offers advanced networking features. It provides intelligent routing, resiliency, and security features, so that service authors don’t have to keep re-implementing them. Istio is rapidly taking off and there are great introductory talks everywhere. However in this session, we will dive deep to explore precisely how it does what it does, following one brave little packet in from the internet and back out again.

item.title: Multi-Cluster Routing - A Multi-Mesh Approach
item.description: Video Alas the videographers let us down. Session Information Meetup Link Abstract Cross-cluster / VPC / Data Center connectivity is a huge problem. Current solutions are clunky and unreliable, using VPNs, DirectConnects, or sending everything out to the internet and back through the ingress layer. Some solutions have been attempted with Service Meshes, but these all involve a shared control plane, causing bit problems for latency, security, and reliability.

item.title: Bash is Testing
item.description: Video Session Information Conference Link Abstract Everyone says they’re coding in Rust these days, but they’re not. Every system has some bash-flavoured blu-tack hiding in the corners. But how well do you know this arcane, abstruse, annoying programming language? In 5 minutes, I’ll educate, entertain, and inform you about a core part of the bash language - the simple conditional statement. This irreverent and funny talk, while yes, insulting bash quite a lot, will hopefully provide a whole bunch of “oh, that’s why it does that” moments too.

item.title: Do you need a Service Mesh?

We’ll explore what a service mesh is and what they can do for your microservice web backends. Are the claims of observability, resiliency, and WAF features real? Are they useful during development, production, or both? Using pictures and demos, we’ll find out! item.title: An Introduction to Userspace Filesystem Development
item.description: Session Information Conference Link Abstract Writing a filesystem can be very cool. Alas, writing a filesystem is also very hard. This is mainly because coding in the kernel is hard. Thankfully, most of the pain can be avoided by using a library like FUSE. Such libraries enable filesystems to be expressed as simple userspace programmes by taking care of all that tedious mucking about in kernel space. This talk will look at the Why and How of such filesystem development, using FUSE on UNIX.
